The game came much hyped, and I loved the previous two BS installments - so purchasing this was a must. Unfortunately, I have to say that I was largely disappointed. The graphics (and the design in general) are beautiful, but the environment and characters are horrendously stiff, and totally unbelievable (what's with everyone leaving around audiologs and ammo? And why no-one bothers while you run around, gun in your hand and possibly covered in blood?). Gameplay-wise, gIven the open-air nature of much of the levels, BSI it plays like  Doom on steroids - which in itself was a plus-one-dimension Space Invaders (enemies come at you in waves, you repel them, move forward). I did maybe 75% of the game without using plasmids once (so much that the game kept telling me to "remember to use" them). Apart from the final battle, the game is really not much of a challenge (haven't bothered with the 1999 mode since I beat it). The story is interesting, Booker DeWitt is an interesting character (never really dug Elizabeth though) and there are enough twists  to keep you interested throughout all the bo-ring pew pew pew gameplay. In sum: looks wonderful; feels stiff; spins a good yarn; boring and mindless to play.
buenos gráficos, increíble banda sonora, una aventura completamente innovada

Bioshock infinite introduces its self as one of the finest light house climbing simulators in the world. You spend minutes taking each step until you reach the top. Once there however, it becomes the worst ever. You get forced away from your lighthouse combing and onto a wierd ass city tour where people become racist and you cut off fingers. Forced to kidnap a woman from a tower of herself, you take her and a giant metal bird across this terrible city and meet all sorts of odd people who seem to have come to hate their racist ways and instead of attacking the irish or black, they attack you, because you are a horrible kidnapping, lighthouse clmbing fool. Also, the bird turns out to be the lock ness monster and ask for tree fiddy, but you do escape, so dont worry.

As a lighthouse sim 5/10. Good, but gets cut short because...

As a horrible person simulator. 8/10. Kidnapping, racism and bird care are all easily depicted.

Bioshock Infinite is a fun first-person shooter, but it's the storytelling and environment that really brings it to life.  A beautifully realised setting that satirises American exceptionalism with a far more subtle touch than the first game's criticism of Rand, Bioshock Infinite lures you in to Columbia subtly - before tackling racism, religion and historical whitewashing with an unashamed daring that all other games lack.  And then it goes further.

As a game, it doesn't _quite_ have anything to match Bioshock's first terrifying fight against a Big Daddy.  But the character development and twisted brilliance of the setting more than make up for that.  Go pay Columbia a visit.
Eins der besten Spiele 2013. Gameplay top, Grafik sehr gut und Story auch sehr gut.
Amazing gameplay and soundtrack that keep you on the edge of your seat the ENTIRE game and an ending definitely worth playing for.
One of the most boring games I've ever played.

BioShock Infinite is a masterfully created work of art. Its vivid and bright textures make for popping visuals, while dull colors of walls and floors prevent from oversaturation. I found myself stopping many times throughout the game just to see the view, which is something that few games have ever made me do. I've also stopped when random dialogue or music pops up. The writing and the music are simply beautiful. On the topic of writing.. the story was very well written. 

My only wish was that the game had been longer, with more story, dialogue, and scenery, and less combat. At heart, Bioshock is not really a combat game, even if there is a huge focus on combat. Its charm lies within its writing, its setting, and its soundtrack. I was simply blown away by its beauty. 

Overall, this game was very enjoyable as an experience. However, that means that there will probably be less to enjoy the second time around (although still enjoyable), as it happens to be just the retelling. 

9/10
While short Infinite provides an interesting setting and world if you take the time to search for the backstory and the visual history presented in the world of Colombia.
Story well told.

This game is fantastic, the story is incredible, and the gameplay is great. Bioshock infinite isn't perfect, in some instances the battles can drag on a bit and there was a section near the end that heavily annoyed me. But these flaws can be overlooked because of the incredible story. The plasmids system from the original Bioshock is replaced with vigors witch act in a simular way, they give power ups that do various other things in the game, these help break up the shooting sections a bit and also bring some new ways to do battle. The blade on the arm is very useful as it allows you to go on skylines which in turn help you get around more easily. Bioshock infinite is one of the best looking games I have ever seen, the environments are bright and colorful and the characters look great as well. The story is the best part of the game, this may be one of the best and most fascinating stories ever told in a video game. I was engaged the entire time I was playing and I won't spoil it, but yeah, I didn't see that coming. The story touches on themes such as racism and religion the characters are great, the protagonist is voiced this time, he is a guy names Booker DeWitt, and he has one mission, to get Elizabeth, Booker and Elizabeth both end up being great in the end and I won't spoil it, but yeah, Overall, Bioshock ininite is a great game and one that changed the way I look at things, and I will definitely play it again to see anything I might have missed. 


I give it a 9.8/10
Шикарная игра с интересным сюжетом. Элизабет FTW =)

Fucking blew me away. Amazing game, very strong character buildup, and you immediately love and cherish all things when you suddenly lose them and gives you a revelation.

Ending is very very very very, wow, terrific.

If you're looking for a very good storyline that lets you pretty much do whatever you want, I would recommend this game.

Это же Биошок *_*

After playing this game numerous times (once on Normal, once on 1999) I can safely say it's one of the best stories of all time. The game, however, sucks.

Lemmie explain. 
In the original Bioshock, you had 7 weapons (8 if you include the Camera) that you can carry on you at any given time. This, coupled with the 3 types of ammo for nearly every weapon, allowed you to approach situations and adjust to them as they came. In addition to the interesting weapons, their upgrades were even more fascinating. The ability to freeze somebody by smacking them over the head, then shoot them with fire bullets? Why not?! The possibilites for an interesting combat experience were endless.

Bosses in the original also had depth, and were interesting characters. You knew them, you saw what they'd done, you'd heard their words, and agreed with why they must die for you to continue onwards. They also had a habbit for knowing when it was high time to fall over, meaning, after their primary mechanic was exploited, their minutes quickly became numbered, creating a fast paced, difficult, non mundane boss fighting experience. It wasn't just the bosses that died without a ridiculous amount of bullets being pumped into their face, regular enemies didn't take half a nuclear arsenal to bring down, and with good reason; they were just drug heads in t-shirts with the occasional power. Nothing more.

My apologies for ranting, but there's a point to this. The reason I mentioned the previous two things in those long drawn out excuses for paragraphs it to show what Infinite is lacking. You can hold a maximum of two weapons (the melee weapon now passively always being attached) and thus decreasing the possible methods of dealing with an issue by an exponentional amount. The upgrades for weapons in Infinite are also a joke, being the standard "Reduced Recoil, Increase Damage, Increase Ammo Capacity". That is boring. This is why I mark off the weapon system as terrible.

The second thing to complain about in this game is the combat sections (if they can even be called that). Interesting locations and cool locales taken thrown headfirst into a game of "Who can be the biggest bullet sponge." The enemies act with a reckless disregard for their own safety and recieve no penalty for it because they can take more hits than an IS-2 tank. It's not interesting fighting enemies who can run up to you and tank all the damage and just punch you in the face. The mess of a combat system quickly becomes a chore when you realize who Ken Levine called in when the bosses all called in sick: Handymen, a dude on fire, and a Spooky Scary Ghost. The Handymen might quite possibly be the worst enemy I have ever faced in a game (besides of course the Lopers from Return to Castle Wolfenstein). They're not enemies so much as they're trucks that can fly. They take a ridiculous amount of punishment and just don't die after being hit in the "Weak Spot" at least 20 times by 12 guage slugs. You also need to fight them every 10 or so minutes, so you spend 1/3 of the game playing and about 2/3s fighting these fun champs, who quickly lose appeal after the first encounter. 

Now onto the good part: The story. Horrible combat aside, Bioshock Infinite is a must buy. The enviroments are diverse and feel real and full of life (until you start shooting but hey then it's full of Up-Till-Recently life), the big enemies/friends you encounter all feel like part of something much bigger than yourself, and the story itself and watching Columbia fall apart is absolutely golden and shouldn't be missed.

An 9/10 story coupled with 3/10 gameplay could easily total to a solid 7.5 game. Highly recommend.

A fun game continuing in the vein of the original.  I had minimal issues with crashes and such completing the game in about 12 hours minus the DLC.

If you enjoyed the first two Bioshock games, you'll love Bioshock Infinite.  While I wish you spent just a little more time in the city of Columbia proper (before the game picks up and throws you to the wolves - so to speak), the city itself is entirely captivating, gorgeous, and it makes you feel as though you have crash landed in a foreign world where something, though you're not sure quite what, is very, very wrong.  The combat is intuitive, but can be a little frustrating at times.  It can quickly become:  a) Pick up Murder of Crows ability, b) Use whatever gun you have currently, c) Win.  

But, while the combat can be a little tiresome and frustratingly frantic, the story... The story completely makes up for whatever flaws the game does have.  The last hour will have you scratching your head with your mouth agape, and you'll find yourself saying "what the hell just happened?" and "oh my god, no waaaaay".  It's a marvelous experience that is definitely worth playing through at least once.  These types of dystopian games that mess with your head are far too few, and gems like this only come once in a while.  

As far as the DLC is concerned, the Burial At Sea DLC is a little too short, but expected from being just Part One of -however many-, and worth the download if only to experience the grandeur of Rapture once again.

Joguei e zerei esse jogo no Xbox. E recentemente pude finalmente comprá-lo no Steam. 

Sou um "gamer" há muito tempo. Já tive um Nintendo 64, todos os Playstations e um Xbox.

O que quero dizer é: NUNCA joguei um jogo tão bem feito, com uma direção de arte tão bem feita, com um cenário tão belo e inovador, com uma PUTA FUCKING FODA HISTÓRIA, com trilha sonora tão bem adaptada, com TUDO tão bem feito como em BioShock Infinite.

O melhor jogo do ano, da geração e de toda a história da humanidade.
Amazing game, gameplay and ending. If you havent played this yet you have NO IDEA what your missing out on. 10/10

I'm in love with the Bioshock series and infinite once again delivers on the promise of great storytelling with stunning visuals. If you've ventured down into Rapture you should already know Irrationale's ability to create an atmosphere that emerses you completely in the game world. I found myself hours later coming back to reality. The mechanics themselves aren't anything too original. Those familiar with the other bioshock games won't find anything too different besides perhaps the skyways. If you're playing Bioshock for the FPS though I'm afraid you might be in for a disappointment.

One of my favorite single player games of all time. An amazing story, wonderful music and fun gameplay mechanics. Also some of the best voice acting I've ever seen. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes story-centric first person shooters.

Bioshock Inifinite sticks with you long after you are done playing. The feeling of living in a U.S. national socialist world is oppressive and in some ways makes you squirm at how plausible the politics seem. The game also makes you think about some theological questions such as the purpose of baptism and how it could be perverted. Politics, faith, racism, family, sacrifice, cults, parallel universes all collide to make Bioshock Infinite a masterpiece. Don't miss it.

One of the best games I've ever played. You will be immersed in the storyline. Offers an alternate view of the universe (you'll see what I mean when you finish it). Feels strange not being in Rapture, but Columbia is just as well polished. The graphics are breathtaking. Play it on Hard for a challenging game experience. 10/10
